title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To study the influence of the local microenvironment on tumour invasion
outcome: we applied spatially resolved transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) to a transgenic zebrafish model of BRAFV600E-driven melanoma
predicted_context: The zebrafish model system offers optical transparency and genetic tractability, enabling high-resolution in vivo imaging of tumor initiation and progression while allowing for the direct observation of interactions between cancer cells and the structural constraints of the surrounding tissue.
predicted_outcome: Generate transgenic zebrafish lines expressing melanoma-driving oncogenes (such as human BRAF(V600E) driven by the MITF promoter) coupled with fluorescent reporters to visually track tumor morphology and cell invasion relative to adjacent tissues.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Across fish, we found a conserved ‘interface’ transcriptional cell state that occurs where tumour cells invade into the microenvironment 6 (12.1% of zebrafish tumour cells; Fig. 1a)
context: Tumours from this model frequently invade into adjacent tissues, including the underlying dermis and muscle
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: Tumor heterogeneity is often spatially organized, where interaction with the surrounding microenvironment at the tumor boundary can impose physical and chemical constraints that drive specific phenotypic adaptations.
predicted_outcome: Consequently, the identification of this distinct interface population indicates that proximity to the microenvironment triggers a reproducible transcriptional reprogramming event, potentially serving as the mechanism initiating tumor invasion.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To investigate whether these interface cells occur in patients
context: a recently published human melanoma scRNA-seq dataset of 7,186 tumour and stromal cells from 31 patients with untreated or immunotherapy-resistant melanoma7
outcome: we analysed a recently published human melanoma scRNA-seq dataset of 7,186 tumour and stromal cells from 31 patients with untreated or immunotherapy-resistant melanoma7 (Fig. 1b and Extended Data Fig. 1a). We scored tumour cells for the relative expression of interface genes from our zebrafish transcriptomic datasets
predicted_context: Since the zebrafish model demonstrated that mechanical confinement at the tumor boundary induces a distinct invasive phenotype with specific molecular signatures, and confirming clinical relevance requires validating this spatial-phenotypic relationship in human pathology.
predicted_outcome: we will perform immunofluorescence or immunohistochemical staining on human melanoma tumor sections to visualize and quantify the expression of invasive state markers specifically at the tumor-stroma interface compared to the tumor core.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content:
a subpopulation of human tumour cells
highly upregulated interface markers (12.3% of tumour cells; Fig. 1c and Extended Data Fig. 1b), mostly from immunotherapy-resistant patients
(Extended Data Fig. 1d–f)
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: Phenotypic plasticity allows melanoma cells to transition into distinct transcriptional states, often regulated by microenvironmental cues, which can drive tumor progression and confer resistance to therapeutic interventions.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the upregulation of interface markers identifies a distinct, clinically relevant cell state enriched in non-responders, indicating that this specific phenotype contributes to immunotherapy resistance.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To better understand the nature of these cells
context: A previous study defined at least four cell states that encompass the melanoma differentiation trajectory (melanocytic, transitory, neural crest-like and undifferentiated)
outcome:
we compared our interface population to human melanoma cell states...We scored tumour and interface cells for the relative expression of gene modules encompassing the entire melanoma cell differentiation trajectory and classified cells into
each of the four states on the basis of their expression of gene modules annotated for that state2.
predicted_context: Since cellular phenotypes, such as the distinction between proliferative and invasive states in melanoma, are defined by underlying gene expression profiles and transcriptional heterogeneity.
predicted_outcome: perform RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) analysis to characterize the transcriptomic landscape of the cell populations.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Although tumour cells were relatively evenly distributed between the four cell states, interface cells showed clear upregulation of genes characteristic of the undifferentiated state (Fig. 1d,e and Extended Data Fig. 1c). ... Interface cells downregulated MITF and SOX10 and upregulated SOX9 (Fig. 1f and Extended Data Fig. 1g). Classical melanocyte pigmentation genes were minimally expressed by interface cells relative to the tumour bulk, including MITF (log2 fold change (FC) = −5.19), TYRP1 (log2FC = −7.75) and PMEL (log2FC = −8.78) (Fig. 1f, Extended Data Fig. 1g and Supplementary Table 1). Unexpectedly, interface cells also upregulated genes involved in neuronal development, including SOX11 (log2FC = 5.15), NNAT (log2FC = 8.61), NEUROD1 (log2FC = 6.22) and NEFM (log2FC = 6.19) (Fig. 1g and Supplementary Table 1). Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) revealed that transcriptional programs linked to cell fate specification and neuronal development were highly enriched in interface cells (Fig. 1h,i).
context: Melanoma behaviour is regulated by phenotype switching, in which cells transition between differentiated/proliferative and undifferentiated/invasive states. The transition between the proliferative and invasive states is regulated by the transcription factors MITF, SOX9 and SOX10, among others8. MITF and SOX10 regulate melanocyte differentiation and proliferation9,10, whereas SOX9 is associated with the undifferentiated invasive state11
outcome: These data indicate that interface cells adopt an invasive state with markers of neuronal development.
predicted_context: Melanocytes originate from the embryonic neural crest, and the simultaneous loss of lineage-specific master regulators (like MITF) and re-expression of neuronal markers is a well-established signature of lineage dedifferentiation towards a multipotent, neural crest-like progenitor state.
predicted_outcome: These transcriptomic changes indicate that the interface microenvironment triggers a lineage regression, where melanoma cells abandon their differentiated melanocytic identity to adopt an undifferentiated, neural crest stem cell-like phenotype.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To examine factors within the local TME that may drive the interface state
outcome: we performed histology on tissue sections from our transgenic zebrafish melanoma model, focusing on the invasive front.
predicted_context: Melanomas primarily initiate within the epidermis, meaning the tumor cells are physically surrounded by and interact directly with keratinocytes. Therefore, these neighboring keratinocytes are the most likely source of environmental cues (paracrine signals or physical contact) that could induce phenotypic plasticity at the tumor interface.
predicted_outcome: Perform in vitro co-culture assays of melanoma cells with keratinocytes and conduct transcriptomic analysis (RNA-seq) to determine if interaction with keratinocytes induces the gene expression signature characteristic of the interface state.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Tumour cells invading into the TME showed elongated nuclei compared with the bulk tumour mass (Fig. 1j,k)
context:
A previous study showed that tumour nuclei become highly elongated when squeezing through mechanically
restrictive environments12.
outcome: Although numerous factors probably influence tumour invasion, we hypothesized that mechanical forces exerted on the cell/nucleus may cause stable changes in gene expression and tumour cell behaviour.
predicted_context: Nuclear elongation and deformation are well-characterized morphological responses of cells subjected to physical confinement or mechanical stress as they migrate through dense tissue matrices.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the invading cells are experiencing significant mechanical confinement within the microenvironment, distinct from the conditions within the bulk tumor, implicating physical forces as a factor in the observed phenotypic heterogeneity.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To test this hypothesis
context: a system to confine human melanoma cells ... in vitro at predefined heights ... using a polydimethylsiloxane piston and micropatterned coverslips13.
outcome: we adapted a system to confine human melanoma cells (A375 cell line) in vitro at predefined heights (3 µm) using a polydimethylsiloxane piston and micropatterned coverslips13 (Fig. 1l).
predicted_context: Zebrafish serve as an ideal model system for investigating the in vivo tumor microenvironment due to their optical transparency and genetic tractability, which allow for real-time visualization of tumor cell morphology and interactions with physical tissue boundaries (confinement) in a living organism.
predicted_outcome: We will utilize transgenic zebrafish melanoma models to perform high-resolution intravital imaging, comparing the phenotypic behavior and cell state markers of tumor cells located in mechanically confined anatomical regions versus those in unconfined areas.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
confined cells did not upregulate apoptosis markers cleaved caspase-3, annexin V or cleaved
PARP (Extended Data Fig. 2a–f).
outcome: Confinement in vitro was not cytotoxic
predicted_context: Cleaved caspase-3, annexin V, and cleaved PARP are canonical biochemical markers used to identify the activation of apoptosis (programmed cell death) in response to cellular stress.
predicted_outcome: This demonstrates that the mechanical confinement applied in this model is not cytotoxic, confirming that the observed cellular responses represent a non-lethal phenotypic adaptation rather than a death response.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
Post-confinement, cells recovered typical morphology within 24 h without widespread cell death (Extended
Data Fig. 2g).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: In the study of phenotypic plasticity, it is essential to distinguish adaptive regulatory responses from permanent cellular damage or the passive selection of resistant subpopulations via toxicity.
predicted_outcome: This indicates that the confinement-induced state is a reversible, plastic adaptation rather than a permanent alteration or an artifact of differential cell survival.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To profile confinement-induced changes in gene expression
outcome: we confined A375 cells for approximately 18 h and performed bulk RNA-seq
predicted_context: Since phenotypic plasticity in melanoma involves transitioning between distinct transcriptional states (e.g., proliferative vs. invasive) driven by microenvironmental cues, a global analysis of the transcriptome is required to identify the specific gene signatures and pathways altered by physical stress.
predicted_outcome: Perform RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) on melanoma cells subjected to mechanical confinement compared to unconfined control cells to quantify differential gene expression.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Principal component analysis revealed considerabletranscriptional alterations induced by confinement (Fig. 1m and Supplementary Table 2).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is well established that distinct cellular phenotypes, such as the switch from proliferation to invasion, are underpinned by specific, global changes in gene expression profiles.
predicted_outcome: These findings indicate that mechanical confinement acts as a sufficient environmental cue to trigger the widespread genomic reprogramming necessary to drive phenotypic plasticity in melanoma cells.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Similar to human interface cells, confined cells upregulated several neuronal pathways (Fig. 1n and Supplementary Table 2). We calculated the overlap between the human interface gene signature and the confined melanoma gene signature (Extended Data Fig. 2h and Supplementary Table 3). Pathway analysis showed that many of the co-regulated genes were related to neuronal development (Extended Data Fig. 2i and Supplementary Table 3).
outcome: These data indicate that confinement causes interface cells to adopt a neuronal identity.
predicted_context: Melanomas originate from the neural crest lineage, and the re-expression of embryonic neural or neural crest markers is a well-established mechanism of dedifferentiation that facilitates motility and invasion.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that mechanical confinement acts as a specific microenvironmental cue that triggers a lineage reversion program, driving melanoma cells to adopt a pseudo-neuronal, invasive identity similar to cells found at the tumor-stroma interface.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: confinement causes interface cells to adopt a neuronal identity
context: Neuronal development relies on microtubule (MT) architecture, influencing almost every aspect of neuronal structure and function14. The cytoskeleton often transmits force within and between cells and remodels in response to mechanical stimuli15. Recent reports indicate that the MT cytoskeleton is stabilized by force to protect confined cells from damage16.
outcome:
We hypothesized that melanoma cells hijack neuronal
mechanisms to allow them to invade into the mechanically confined microenvironment ... confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons
predicted_context: Melanoma cells originate from the neural crest, a multipotent embryonic lineage that naturally possesses the developmental capacity to differentiate into various cell types, including neurons.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that mechanical stress exerts sufficient pressure to reactivate latent developmental programs, driving a specific lineage transdifferentiation that likely supports an invasive phenotype.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We hypothesized that melanoma cells hijack neuronal mechanisms to allow them to invade into the mechanically confined microenvironment ... confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons
outcome: We used our in vitro confinement system to characterize how force remodels the MT cytoskeleton by imaging A375 cells labelled with the MT vital dye SiR-tubulin
predicted_context: Neuronal morphology and the structural integrity of neurites are maintained by the stabilization of microtubules, a process fundamentally regulated by specific microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs), such as MAP2, which are typically restricted to neural lineages.
predicted_outcome: Perform immunofluorescence staining and gene expression analysis to evaluate the induction and localization of the neuronal dendritic marker MAP2 in melanoma cells subjected to mechanical confinement.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confinement extensively remodelled the MT cytoskeleton; within 2–4 h, curved MTs began encircling the cell and nuclear periphery (Fig. 2a,b).
context:
This was reminiscent of a previous study that showed that MTs bend to prevent buckling
or rupture in response to force16
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: Microtubules are stiff cytoskeletal elements that provide structural rigidity and are known to reorganize under mechanical stress to resist compression and maintain cellular integrity.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the formation of a microtubule cage around the nucleus is a protective adaptation to shield the nucleus and cellular architecture from the physical pressure of confinement.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We also observed loss of a central MT organizing centre with radial MTs
context: reminiscent of neurons with centrosome-independent MT organization14,17.
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: Radial microtubule arrays anchored at a central organizing center are characteristic structural hallmarks of polarized, proliferative cells.
predicted_outcome: This cytoskeletal reorganization indicates a departure from cell polarity and division capacity, supporting the conclusion that the cells have transitioned from a proliferative to an invasive state.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Curved MTs, such as those we observed in confined cells
context:
Acetylated tubulin mediates neuronal architecture and function and marks axonal MTs18. Tubulin acetylation stabilizes MTs and thus the cell against mechanical pressure19. Curved MTs, such as those we observed in confined cells (Fig. 2a,b), are also indicative of long-lived,
stabilized MTs19.
outcome: enrichment of acetylated tubulin at the tumour border
predicted_context: Microtubules are inherently stiff structural components, and significant curvature or buckling is typically a biophysical signature of compressive mechanical loading acting upon the cytoskeleton.
predicted_outcome: This indicates that the confinement places the cells under distinct mechanical stress, which likely acts as the physical transducer driving the chromatin remodeling and the transition to an invasive phenotype.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: enrichment of acetylated tubulin at the tumour border?
outcome: We performed immunofluorescence on sections from adult fish with transgenic BRAFV600E-driven melanomas
predicted_context: Acetylated tubulin is a marker of stable microtubules, which provide structural support and mechanical resistance to cells under compressive stress, a condition expected to be most intense at the interface where the expanding tumor meets the confining surrounding tissue.
predicted_outcome: Perform immunofluorescence staining on melanoma tumor sections using antibodies specific for acetylated tubulin and quantify fluorescence intensity at the tumor periphery compared to the tumor core.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confining A375 cells in vitro also resulted in significant upregulation of acetylated tubulin (P = 6.86 × 10−12; Fig. 2f–h). Acetylated tubulin filaments in unconfined cells were typically short and linear, whereas in confined cells, acetylated tubulin filaments were longer and more curved—again indicative of stabilization (Fig. 2f,g).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: Acetylation of alpha-tubulin is a well-established post-translational modification that serves as a marker for stable, long-lived microtubules, distinguishing them from the highly dynamic, non-acetylated population.
predicted_outcome: Therefore, mechanical confinement induces a significant reorganization of the cytoskeleton in melanoma cells, specifically promoting microtubule stability and longevity as an adaptive structural response to physical restriction.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We noticed that in confined cells, the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear (Fig. 2f,g)
context:
As the stiffest and largest organelle, the nucleus is vulnerable to confinement-induced
stress, with confined migration often causing nuclear envelope rupture and DNA damage20,21. During migration through confined spaces, neurons assemble a perinuclear network of acetylated tubulin to protect the nucleus22,23.
outcome: hypothesized that this network may provide structural support to the nucleus
predicted_context: Hyperacetylated microtubules are known to be stiffer and more stable than their non-acetylated counterparts, providing structural rigidity to the cytoskeleton.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the reorganization of these stable microtubules serves to form a protective mechanical 'cage' around the nucleus to prevent nuclear deformation or damage under conditions of physical confinement.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
We confirmed the stability of the perinuclear MT
network
context: nocodazole, which induces MT disassembly through an acetylation-independent mechanism24...Acetylated MTs are resistant to nocodazole19
outcome: by treating confined cells with nocodazole
predicted_context: Microtubules exhibit varying degrees of stability, and resistance to depolymerizing agents like nocodazole is a standard biochemical property used to distinguish stable, long-lived microtubule populations from dynamic ones.
predicted_outcome: Melanoma cells were treated with nocodazole to depolymerize the dynamic cytoskeleton, followed by imaging to assess the persistence of the perinuclear microtubule ring.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Nocodazole (1 µM) induced the disassembly of almost all non-modified tubulin filaments in both unconfined and confined cells (Fig. 2i,j). Although unconfined nocodazole treated cells exhibited minimal acetylated tubulin, many confined nocodazole-treated cells contained a perinuclear acetylated tubulin cage (Fig. 2i,j).
outcome: N/A
predicted_context: It is well established that tubulin acetylation serves as a marker for long-lived, stable microtubules that typically exhibit resistance to depolymerizing agents (such as nocodazole) compared to the dynamic, non-modified tubulin population.
predicted_outcome: These findings imply that mechanical confinement specifically triggers the formation and stabilization of a resistant microtubule architecture (the perinuclear cage), rendering it structurally distinct from the labile cytoskeleton found in unconfined cells.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Which acetyltransferase that responds to mechanical stress in melanoma cells by stabilizing the tubulin cytoskeleton.
outcome: We generated a stable A375 cell line, in which the main eukaryotic tubulin acetyltransferase (ATAT1) was inactivated using CRISPR (Extended Data Fig. 3a,b),
predicted_context: Alpha-tubulin acetyltransferase 1 (TAT1) is the primary enzyme known to acetylate alpha-tubulin at Lysine 40, a modification that increases microtubule flexibility and resistance to mechanical breakage, thereby stabilizing the cytoskeleton under physical stress.
predicted_outcome: Perform shRNA-mediated knockdown of TAT1 in melanoma cells subjected to mechanical confinement and assess microtubule stability and acetylation levels using immunofluorescence and western blotting.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We generated a stable A375 cell line, in which the main eukaryotic tubulin acetyltransferase (ATAT1) was inactivated using CRISPR (Extended Data Fig. 3a,b), and found that this almost completely abolished acetylated tubulin, including the perinuclear network (Extended Data Fig. 3c–e).
outcome: This indicates that ATAT1 is the acetyltransferase that responds to mechanical stress in melanoma cells by stabilizing the tubulin cytoskeleton.
predicted_context: It is scientifically established that ATAT1 is the specific enzyme responsible for catalyzing the acetylation of alpha-tubulin (typically at Lysine 40), a post-translational modification essential for stabilizing long-lived microtubules and maintaining the structural integrity of the perinuclear cage.
predicted_outcome: Consequently, this confirms the successful generation of a loss-of-function model, demonstrating that the perinuclear microtubule network in A375 cells is strictly dependent on ATAT1-mediated acetylation.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear
context: In addition to acetylation, MTs exhibit a variety of post-translational modifications (PTMs), including tyrosination, glutamylation, glycylation and methylation, which influence MT stability25.
outcome: clarify the composition of the perinuclear tubulin network
predicted_context: Acetylation of alpha-tubulin is a modification associated with stable, long-lived microtubules that provide mechanical rigidity and are known to form a protective cage around the nucleus to prevent rupture during cell migration through narrow spaces.
predicted_outcome: This indicates that melanoma cells adapt to mechanical confinement by reinforcing the cytoskeleton around the nucleus, thereby creating a shield to preserve nuclear integrity during the transition to an invasive state.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To clarify the composition of the perinuclear tubulin network
outcome: we used immunofluorescence to characterize MT PTMs in confined melanoma cells
predicted_context: Post-translational modifications of microtubules regulate their stability and function, with acetylation of alpha-tubulin specifically marking stable, long-lived microtubule populations often found in perinuclear structures that resist mechanical stress, as opposed to dynamic tyrosinated tubulin.
predicted_outcome: Perform immunofluorescence staining using antibodies specific for acetylated alpha-tubulin and tyrosinated alpha-tubulin to visualize and distinguish the specific modification state of the microtubules in the perinuclear region.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: most MTs in confined and unconfined A375 cells were highly tyrosinated (Extended Data Fig. 4a–d)
context: Detyrosination has been linked to stabilized MTs26
outcome: probably owing to the high concentrations of tyrosine and tyrosinase in melanoma27
predicted_context: It is an established principle in cell biology that tubulin tyrosination is a marker of dynamic, labile microtubules, whereas detyrosinated tubulin characterizes stable, long-lived microtubule populations.
predicted_outcome: This suggests that the microtubule network within these melanoma cells remains predominantly dynamic and unstable, rather than forming rigid, stable structures, regardless of whether the cells are subjected to mechanical confinement.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Although confined perinuclear MTs were occasionally tyrosinated and rarely detyrosinated (Extended Data Fig. 4a–d), there was no specific enrichment of these PTMs in the perinuclear network, as observed for acetylated MTs. Similar results were observed for poly-glutamylated MTs (Extended Data Fig. 4e,f). No polyglycylated MTs were found in either condition (Extended Data Fig. 4g,h).
outcome: This indicates that acetylation is the primary PTM mediating the assembly and/or stability of the perinuclear tubulin network
predicted_context: Microtubule stability and function are regulated by a 'tubulin code' of diverse post-translational modifications (PTMs), where specific modifications typically correspond to distinct mechanical properties or cellular states (e.g., acetylation often marks stable, long-lived microtubules).
predicted_outcome: This lack of enrichment for other common modifications indicates that the formation of the perinuclear microtubule network under mechanical confinement is a highly specific structural adaptation defined uniquely by acetylation, rather than a generalized response involving broad microtubule alterations.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content:
These results indicate that confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons ...Acetylated tubulin
filaments in unconfined cells were typically short and linear, whereas in confined cells, acetylated tubulin filaments were longer and more curved—again indicative of stabilization ...We noticed that in confined cells, the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear (Fig. 2f,g)
outcome: These data indicate that confined melanoma cells assemble a stable perinuclear tubulin network to reinforce the nucleus against mechanical stress, similar to neurons.
predicted_context: It is well established that the acetylation of alpha-tubulin is a marker of stable, long-lived microtubules, which provide structural rigidity and are often associated with cells undergoing morphological differentiation (such as neurons) or adapting to resist mechanical stress.
predicted_outcome: Therefore, mechanical confinement induces the stabilization of the microtubule network, particularly around the nucleus, enabling the melanoma cells to withstand physical compression and adopt the structural plasticity required for the transition to an invasive, neuron-like phenotype.
